bill.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 164, Number 180 (Wednesday, November 14, 2018)]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. YOUNG of Alaska:H.R. 7135.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8The constitutional authority of Congress to enact thislegislation is provided by Article I, section 8 of the UnitedStates Constitution (clauses 3 and 18), which grants Congressthe power to regulate commerce with foreign nations and amongthe several states; and to make all laws which shall benecessary and proper for carrying into execution theforegoing powers.____________________[Page H9526]

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure.

bill.title: To direct the Secretary of the department in which the Coast Guard is operating to issue a certificate of documentation with a coastwise endorsement for the vessel Pacific Provider.

item.title: To direct the Secretary of the department in which the Coast Guard is operating to issue a certificate of documentation with a coastwise endorsement for the vessel Pacific Provider.
To direct the Secretary of the department in which the Coast Guard is operating to issue a certificate of documentation with a coastwise endorsement for the vessel Pacific Provider.

item.text: This bill authorizes the Coast Guard to issue a certificate of documentation with a coastwise endorsement for the vessel Pacific Provider (United States official number 597967).
item.name: Introduced in House

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Transportation and Infrastructure.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
